But Mr. Brunner expected
en_second_half: me to be as good as everybody else, despite the fact that I have dyslexia and attention deficit disorder and I had never made above a C- in my life. No-he didn’t expect me to be as good; he expected me to be better. And I just couldn’t learn all those names and facts, much less spell them correctly.
en_results: us to be able to do this every day, not just on tournament days, and he didn't care if we were tired or if we had a headache or if we just didn't feel like it. en_results_raw: us to be able to do this every day, not just on tournament days, and he didn't care if we were tired or if we had a headache or if we just didn't feel like it. He would stand there, his eyes gleaming with a fierce intensity, his armor glinting in the fluorescent lights, and he would say, "Come now, class, surely you remember the great-grandmother of Pericles?" or "What about the favorite deity of that young man who threw himself off the cliff rather than be captured by the enemy?" And we would stumble and stutter and try to remember, and sometimes we would get it right, but more often we would get it wrong, and Mr. Brunner would shake his head and say, "Unacceptable, unacceptable," and make us try again. It was exhausting, but it was also exhilarating, because when we finally did get it right, when we finally remembered the name of that obscure Roman general or the mythological figure who had turned himself into a tree, we felt a rush of pride and accomplishment that we had never felt before. And Mr. Brunner would smile, a small, fierce smile, and say, "Ah, yes, now you are learning," and we would feel like we were on top of the world.

I spent hours poring over my notes and textbook, trying to commit everything to memory. Meanwhile, I barely glanced at my notes for my other classes, figuring that I could always cram for those tests at the last minute. As a result, I felt relatively confident about Latin, but not so much about my other subjects. On the day of the Latin test, I walked into the classroom feeling focused and prepared, but as I scanned the room, I noticed that my classmates seemed just as confident as I did. I wondered if I had been foolish to focus so much on Latin, and whether I had neglected my other subjects too much.

en_first_half: Outside, nothing but rain and darkness-the kind of empty countryside you get way out on the tip of Long Island. I thought about Mrs. Dodds and the moment
en_second_half: when she’d changed into the thing with pointed teeth and leathery wings. My limbs went numb from delayed shock. She really hadn’t been human. She’d meant to kill me.
en_results: when she had stood in the doorway of my apartment, her eyes fixed on me with a mixture of sadness and warning. The memory of her words, "They're waiting for you," sent
en_results_raw: when she had stood in the doorway of my apartment, her eyes fixed on me with a mixture of sadness and warning. The memory of her words, "They're waiting for you," sent a shiver down my spine as I gazed out into the desolate night. The rain-soaked fields and trees seemed to stretch on forever, like skeletal fingers reaching out to snatch me back into the darkness. I felt a presence behind me and turned to see my host, Mr. Jenkins, standing in the doorway, his face a mask of concern. "Can I get you something, kid?" he asked, his voice low and gravelly. I hesitated, unsure of how much to reveal, but something about his kind eyes put me at ease. "Just trying to clear my head," I replied, turning back to the window. The rain showed no signs of letting up, and I wondered if I'd ever be able to shake the feeling of being watched that had been following me since I arrived on Long Island.

es_results_raw: de Haviland y en cómo me había hablado de Gatsby, de cómo había sido su amiga. Me pregunté si sabría algo sobre él, si podría decirme algo que me ayudara a entenderlo mejor. I felt a shiver run down my spine as I realized that our peaceful afternoon was about to take a drastic turn.

en_first_half: The rest of the day, I’d rotate through outdoor activities, looking for something I was good at. Chiron tried to teach me archery, but we found out
en_second_half: pretty quick I wasn’t any good with a bow and arrow. He didn’t complain, even when he had to desnag a stray arrow out of his tail.
en_results: that I was absolutely terrible at it, and the other campers started to get a little nervous every time I picked up a bow. I tried to
en_results_raw: that I was absolutely terrible at it, and the other campers started to get a little nervous every time I picked up a bow. I tried to make up for it by excelling at capture the flag, but it turned out I was more of a liability on the battlefield than a valuable asset. As the day drew to a close, I couldn't help but feel a little discouraged - it seemed like I just wasn't cut out for this whole demigod thing. But then, just as we were all heading back to the cabins for dinner, I stumbled upon something that would change everything: a game of pinochle with a group of older campers. It was love at first sight - or rather, love at first shuffle of the cards. I had never played before, but something about the strategy and skill involved just clicked with me, and before I knew it, I was hooked. For the first time all day, I felt like I was actually good at something, and it was an incredible feeling. Little did I know, this was only the beginning of an epic adventure that would take me to the heights of Mount Olympus and back again.

en_results_raw: the balance was off, throwing my entire swing out of whack. I had tried every type of sword I could get my hands on, from the elegant rapiers of the fencers to the sturdy broadswords of the knights, but none of them felt like an extension of myself. It was as if I was fighting the sword, rather than with it. I was beginning to lose hope, wondering if I would ever find the perfect blade, one that would allow me to unlock my true potential as a warrior. Just when I thought I had exhausted all my options, I stumbled upon a small, mysterious shop tucked away in a forgotten alley. The sign above the door read "Magical Arms and Armor," and I felt a spark of curiosity ignite within me.

es_results_raw: Me sentía como Goldilocks, pero en lugar de buscar un tazón de avena o una cama, estaba en busca de la espada perfecta. Recuerdo haber probado una que parecía hecha para un gigante, con una hoja tan ancha como mi antebrazo y un mango que parecía un tronco de árbol. Me sentí ridículo intentando blandirla, como un niño pequeño tratando de usar el cinturón de su padre. Luego, encontré una que era lo opuesto, tan ligera que parecía un juguete, y me preocupaba que se rompiera en mi mano en el momento menos esperado. Pero ninguna de ellas se sentía como la mía, como si estuviera destinada a ser empuñada por otra persona.

As I took a long swig, the cool liquid slid down my parched throat, providing a moment of sweet relief from the sweltering heat. The break was a welcome respite, and I took a moment to scan the group, noticing that everyone was chatting and laughing, their faces flushed from exertion. Our coach, a grizzled old-school type with a penchant for pushing us to our limits, stood off to the side, eyeing us with a critical gaze, no doubt already planning the next phase of our training. I took another swig of water, feeling the sweat trickle down my face, and wondered what the rest of the day had in store for us.

La gente jadeaba y se abanicaba con cualquier cosa que tuvieran a mano, intentando encontrar algún alivio del calor asfixiante. El descanso se convirtió en una lucha por la supervivencia, y el refrigerador de bebidas era el único aliado que tenían en esa batalla.

The air was thick with the scent of blooming flowers and fresh earth, but beneath that, I could sense something else - a faint tang of smoke and ash. Suddenly, Annabeth's grip on my arm tightened, and she pulled me back into the shadows. "What is it?" I whispered, but she just shook her head, her eyes fixed intently on something in the distance. I followed her gaze, but all I saw was the darkness of the woods, the flickering fireflies, and the faint outline of a figure moving stealthily through the trees.

The police investigation that followed revealed a tangled web of secrets and lies that led them to question everyone who had come into contact with the pair during their ill-fated trip. As the search for the missing duo continued, the community was left to wonder what could have driven them to flee in such a hurry, and what had really happened in those final, fateful hours. Theories ranged from a violent confrontation to a desperate attempt to escape the pressures of their daily lives, but one thing was certain: the truth, much like the missing pair, remained elusive. The only clue was a cryptic message scrawled on a piece of paper found in the car, which read: "The truth is in the light." What it meant, only time would tell.

The air grew colder, and I felt a presence closing in around me, making the hairs on the back of my neck stand on end. I tried to shake off the feeling, telling myself it was just my imagination playing tricks on me, but I couldn't shake the sense that I was being watched by unseen eyes. The mist seemed to be taking on a life of its own, swirling and eddying around me in a maddening dance. I felt a shiver run down my spine as I realized that I was completely alone in the room, with no one to turn to for help. And then, just as suddenly as it had started, everything stopped. The lights steadied, the mist dissipated, and the jars were still once more. But I knew that I had experienced something inexplicable, something that would haunt me for the rest of my days.

en_second_half: in two major fights the very first day out from camp. At this rate, we’d never make it to L.A. alive, much less before the summer solstice.
en_results: stranded in the middle of nowhere, for making us fight mythological monsters and deal with crazy demigods, and for not giving us any clear answers
en_results_raw: stranded in the middle of nowhere, for making us fight mythological monsters and deal with crazy demigods, and for not giving us any clear answers or help when we needed it most. I felt like we were just pawns in some much larger game, and it wasn't fair. I kicked at the dirt, trying to release some of my frustration, but it only seemed to grow. Annabeth, sensing my anger, approached me cautiously, her eyes filled with concern. "Percy, what's wrong?" she asked, but I just shook my head, unable to put my feelings into words. We stood there in silence for a moment, the only sound being the distant rumble of thunder, a reminder that our journey was far from over.

She was dressed in a flowing white gown, and her presence seemed to command the attention of everyone in the room. I felt a shiver run down my spine as she beckoned me towards her, the sword still clutched in my hand. I approached her hesitantly, unsure of what to expect, but she simply smiled and placed a hand on my shoulder. You are the chosen one, Percy, she said, her voice barely above a whisper. The fate of our kingdom rests in your hands.

en_second_half: the very least, the mortal police would be arriving, trying to figure out who had blown a hole in the Arch. If they found me, they’d have some questions.
en_results: least, that's what I was thinking as I pulled the sword free from the muck and mire, its familiar weight a comforting presence in my hand. I gave it a few
en_results_raw: least, that's what I was thinking as I pulled the sword free from the muck and mire, its familiar weight a comforting presence in my hand. I gave it a few experimental swings, feeling the satisfying whoosh of the blade cutting through the air, and then I set off towards the trees, my senses on high alert for any sign of movement. The forest was quiet, the only sound the soft rustle of leaves and the creaking of branches in the gentle breeze, but I knew that could change at any moment. I moved cautiously, my eyes scanning the underbrush for any sign of the Chimera or its mother, my heart pounding in my chest with anticipation. As I walked, the trees seemed to grow closer together, casting deep, ominous shadows on the ground, and I couldn't shake the feeling that I was being watched. Suddenly, a twig snapped behind me, and I spun around, Riptide at the ready, prepared to face whatever was coming my way.

Su mirada se encontró con la mía y, por un instante, nos quedamos allí, sin decir nada, mientras el silencio entre nosotros parecía cobrar vida propia. I cleared my throat to announce my presence, and Luke spun around, his sword still clutched in his hand. For a moment, we just stared at each other, the only sound the heavy breathing and the creaking of the old wooden dummies. Then, Luke's face relaxed into a wry smile, and he lowered his sword, wiping the sweat from his brow with the back of his hand. "Hey," he said, his voice a little breathless. "I didn't expect to see you here." I shrugged, feeling a little awkward. "I could say the same about you." Luke chuckled and nodded towards the dummies. "Just getting in some practice. I've got a tournament coming up, and I don't want to embarrass myself." I raised an eyebrow. "A tournament? You never mentioned that before." Luke shrugged. "I didn't think it was a big deal. But I guess it's kind of a big deal, now that I think about it." He paused, looking at me with a curious expression. "You want to join me? I could use a sparring partner." I hesitated for a moment, unsure if I was ready for this. But then I nodded, feeling a spark of excitement ignite within me. "Sure," I said, trying to sound casual. "Why not?"
